alfredsnippet.snippet:
(cont'd)

"... The task before those who wish to grasp what kinds of lives have in the past been led ... [is] to conceive what kind of vision of the world men who used a particular kind of language [or myth or rite] must have had for this type of language [or myth or rite] to be a natural expression of it ... We must therefore ask ourselves what the world must have been like for those to whom such use of language, which is almost meaningless to us, made sense ... We must ask what kind of experience is presupposed by, renders intelligible, a particular use of symbols ..., what particular vision is embodied in myths, in religious rites, in inscriptions, in the monuments of the past ... [We must make] an attempt to conceive what the experience of a particular society must have been like for this or that myth, or mode of worship, or language, or building, to be their characteristic expression.' ..."

(cont'd)
